item.title: Yemen’s Ex-President Killed as Mayhem Convulses Capital
item.media:description: Former president Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen at a rally with his supporters in Sana, Yemen, in August.
item.description: The death of the former president, Ali Abdullah Saleh, could plunge war-torn Yemen into new chaos.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Brexit Talks Hit Hurdle as D.U.P. Balks at Irish Border Plan
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May of Britain and the European Commission president, Jean-Claude Juncker, before a meeting in Brussels on Monday.
item.description: A Northern Irish party scuppered a deal Prime Minister Theresa May had reached with the E.U., denying her a much-needed breakthrough in the stalled talks.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Warrant for Carles Puigdemont, Catalan Separatist, Is Dropped
item.media:description: The ousted Catalan leader Carles Puigdemont, third from left, at an event in Brussels with mayors and former councillors from the region this month.
item.description: Mr. Puigdemont and four former members of his cabinet had fled to Belgium, saying they could not receive a fair trial at home.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Kremlin Denies Flynn Influenced Decision on Sanctions
item.media:description: Michael T. Flynn, the former national security adviser to President Trump, after his plea hearing in Washington last week.
item.description: A spokesman said President Putin makes his own decisions, and besides, never knew that Michael T. Flynn had asked Russia not to retaliate for sanctions imposed by President Obama.
item.dc:creator: IVAN NECHEPURENKO
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: North Korea’s Missile Launch Gave Airline Pilots a Jolt
item.media:description: North Korea released this photo, which it said showed the launch of its Hwasong-15 missile on Wednesday. Crews from three commercial jets reported seeing its re-entry over the Sea of Japan.
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.description: Crews from three commercial flights reported seeing what appeared to be the missile the North launched last week. Experts said the risk to planes was low but real.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Reza Zarrab, Taped in Jail, Said Lying Was Ticket to Freedom
item.media:description: “Reza says in such a country, in order to get out or get a reduced sentence, you need to admit to crimes you haven’t committed.” Reza Zarrab in 2013.
item.description: “To get out or get a reduced sentence, you need to admit to crimes you haven’t committed,” the prosecution witness in an Iran sanctions case said.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: Five Strongmen, and the Fate of the Arab Spring
item.media:description: Four leaders waved from a motorcade before an Arab Cooperation Council meeting in Egypt in 1989. From left, Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen, Saddam Hussein of Iraq, King Hussein of Jordan, and Hosni Mubarak of Egypt. Mr. Saleh was reported to have been killed on Monday.
item.description: Leaders of five countries at the heart of the protests that erupted in 2011 — Egypt, Libya, Syria, Tunisia and Yemen — have met very different fates.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )

item.title: Malta Arrests 10 Over Killing of Journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia
item.media:description: The wreckage of the car in which the journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia was killed in October.
item.description: The investigative reporter, who uncovered corruption in high places, was killed by a car bomb in October. Her death fueled outrage and drew thousands to demonstrate.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Krefeld Journal: The German Amateurs Who Discovered ‘Insect Armageddon’
item.media:description: Thomas Hörren, a member of the Entomological Society Krefeld, collecting beetles from a soil sample.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Keeping meticulous records over decades, the Krefeld Entomological Society documented a 75 percent decline in bug populations that shocked the world.
item.dc:creator: SALLY McGRANE

item.title: China Will Lead an Electric Car Future, Ford’s Chairman Says
item.media:description: Fords at an auto show in Guangzhou, China, last month. Ford Motor said Tuesday that it planned to introduce 15 models in China by 2025 that run at least in part on batteries.
item.description: Ford Motor said Tuesday that it planned to offer 15 new models in China by 2025 that run at least in part on batteries.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Son of Slain Yemen Leader Is Said to Vow Revenge
item.media:description: The presidential palace in Sana, Yemen, on Tuesday, after warplanes from a Saudi-led coalition struck it and other targets, news reports said.
item.description: The warning by Ahmed Ali Saleh, an American-trained former military commander, could signal his emergence as a focus of opposition to Houthi rebels.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ALAN COWELL

item.title: Google Missed Out on China. Can It Flourish in India?
item.media:description: Cellphone users in Jodhpur, India, where Google sent a researcher this week to get feedback about apps. Google is changing core products in India to use less data and work better on low-end smartphones.
item.media:credit: Rebecca Conway for The New York Times
item.description: As major companies chase India’s new internet users, Google is changing core products to work better on low-end smartphones and use less data.
item.dc:creator: VINDU GOEL

item.title: Amazon’s Australian Launch Brings Excitement, Dread and Defiance
item.media:description: Amazon’s debut in the Australian marketplace featured only a few hundred sellers – or third-party vendors.
item.description: The retail giant launched with a modest product offering, seeking to steal a piece of Australia’s retail sector.
item.dc:creator: ADAM BAIDAWI

item.title: Honduran Vote Recount Urged as Tally Shows President Is Ahead
item.description: Honduran election officials said President Juan Orlando Hernández had won a narrow margin of votes, but international monitors asked for recounts.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Australia Diary: Australia Diary: Kindness, Poetry and Song
item.media:description: The huge and terrifying huntsman spider.
item.description: The first installment of a new weekly feature, collecting reader tales from Australia.
item.dc:creator: DIANA OLIVA CAVE

item.title: Utah, Roy Moore, Travel Ban: Your Monday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: KAREN ZRAICK and SANDRA STEVENSON

item.title: Ali Abdullah Saleh, Strongman Who Helped Unite Yemen, and Divide It, Dies at 75
item.media:description: Ali Abdullah Saleh of Yemen at the presidential palace in Sana in 2008.
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: A former president who left a legacy of corruption, he re-emerged to play a major role in his country’s civil war.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Supreme Court Allows Trump Travel Ban to Take Effect
item.media:description: The Supreme Court in Washington. The third and newest version of the travel ban, issued by President Trump in September, imposed restrictions on citizens of Chad, Iran, Libya, North Korea, Somalia, Syria, Venezuela and Yemen.
item.description: The decision was a victory for the administration after its mixed success before the court over the summer, when justices considered and later dismissed disputes over the second version.
item.dc:creator: ADAM LIPTAK

item.title: Eurogroup, Looking Past Period of Crisis, Picks New Leader From Portugal
item.media:description: Mário Centeno, Portugal’s finance minister, was chosen to be the new leader of the Eurogroup, which manages crises for the eurozone.
item.description: The selection of Mario Centeno reflects a shift by the Eurogroup, which has grappled with the near-constant collapse of the euro in recent years.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: Cyclone Lashes Southern India, Killing at Least 21
item.media:description: Residents tried makeshift barriers to block sea water from entering their homes after flooding caused by Cyclone Ockhi in Chellanam in the southern state of Kerala, India, on Saturday.
item.description: The extent of the damage was unclear and dozens of fishermen were still missing as high winds and flooding swept the area.
item.dc:creator: KAI SCHULTZ

item.title: Judge Frees Some Jailed Catalan Separatists, but Holds Others
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Barcelona, Spain, last month held banners in Catalan that read, “Freedom for the political prisoners.”
item.description: Six backers of the independence effort were allowed out on bail, but four others — including the former deputy leader of the region — remained in custody.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Gay Australian Politician Proposes During Same-Sex Marriage Debate
item.media:description: Tim Wilson, a liberal member of Parliament in Australia, during a debate Monday about same-sex marriage in which he proposed to his partner, Ryan Bolger.
item.media:credit: Lukas Coch/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.description: The marriage proposal came as a bill legalizing same-sex unions made its way through the final stages of passage in Parliament.
item.dc:creator: ISABELLA KWAI
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: U.S. and South Korea Start Air Force Drills Amid Heightened Tensions
item.media:description: A United States Air Force F-22 Raptor taking off Monday from an air base in Gwangju, South Korea.
item.description: The exercises will include simulated strikes on North Korean nuclear and missile testing sites and come a week after the North tested a ballistic missile.
item.dc:creator: GERRY MULLANY
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talk of a Peace Plan That Snubs Palestinians Roils Middle East
item.media:description: Tourists with a panoramic view of Jerusalem’s Old City.
item.description: A plan that the Saudi crown prince was said to foist on the Palestinians would offer them limited sovereignty and deny them Jerusalem as the capital.
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD, DAVID M. HALBFINGER and PETER BAKER

item.title: Huge Protests in Honduras as Contested Vote Crisis Escalates
item.media:description: Supporters of Salvador Nasralla, the main presidential opposition candidate, protesting in Tegucigalpa, Honduras, on Sunday.
item.description: Marchers demanded an impartial count of last week’s presidential vote as negotiations between the electoral commission and the opposition broke down.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Venezuela Plans a Cryptocurrency, Maduro Says
item.description: The “petro” will be used in the country’s fight against the Trump administration’s financial “blockade,” President Nicolas Maduro said.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Corsican Nationalists Make Strong Showing in Election
item.description: Nationalists running in the French Mediterranean island’s territorial election won almost half the vote. The second will take place on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Quits Migration Pact, Saying It Infringes on Sovereignty
item.media:description: Migrants rescued on the Mediterranean Sea, off the Libyan coast, in August.
item.description: Critics said the Trump administration’s withdrawal from U.N. talks on the migration crisis had reinforced an image of renewed American isolationism.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Help Assad or Leave Cities in Ruins? The Politics of Rebuilding Syria
item.media:description: Syria has been ravaged by years of war, but President Bashar al-Assad is still in power. In July, his portrait hung in Al Waer, once a well-to-do area of Homs, now a ghost of its former self.
item.description: Ravaged areas in the city of Homs symbolize President Assad’s ruthless tactics and embody a looming challenge as the war approaches an end: the politics of reconstruction.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: China’s A.I. Advances Help Its Tech Industry, and State Security
item.media:description: Liu Qingfeng, the chairman of iFlyTek, after his presentation at a conference in Beijing about artificial intelligence.
item.media:credit: Giulia Marchi for The New York Times
item.description: Global car brands and Chinese authorities alike embrace iFlyTek’s voice recognition know-how, illustrating the dystopian possibilities behind the technology.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR and KEITH BRADSHER
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: The New York Times Is Awarded German Prize for ‘International Understanding’
item.media:description: President Frank-Walter Steinmeier of Germany, center, awarding the Marion Dӧnhoff Prize to Arthur O. Sulzberger Jr., right, the publisher of The New York Times, and to Dean Baquet, its executive editor.
item.media:credit: Augustin Christian/Rex Features, via Associated Press
item.description: At a ceremony in Hamburg, the German president praised The Times as “a flagship of freedom of the press” and “a beacon of reason in an age of rampant unreason.”
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Trudeau Steps Up on Trade for Canada, as America Under Trump Pulls Back
item.media:description: Prime Minister Justin Trudeau arriving in Beijing on Sunday.
item.media:credit: Sean Kilpatrick/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.description: Partly as insurance against Nafta’s collapse and perhaps a way to show Washington it has options, Canada is chasing after other free trade deals.
item.dc:creator: IAN AUSTEN and ANA SWANSON

item.title: As China Rises, Australia Asks Itself: Can It Rely on America?
item.media:description: United States Marines marching in Darwin, Australia, this year on Anzac Day, a day of remembrance for veterans. The United States has long been Australia’s security guarantor.
item.media:credit: David Dare Parker for The New York Times
item.description: The government and a prominent strategist clash on whether the United States will remain dominant in Asia, and whether Australia should go it alone.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ and DAMIEN CAVE
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: 11-Year-Old Has Spent Her Life in Jail, a Serial Killer as a Cellmate
item.media:description: Shirin Gul and her daughter Meena, 11, in the women’s wing of the Nangarhar provincial prison, in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, where Ms. Gul is serving a life sentence.
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.description: Meena, an Afghan girl born behind bars, has never been outside, and her convicted mother can keep her until she is 18. She is not the only child there, either.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: She Wants Independence. Is That Dangerous?
item.description: Esraa is looking to rent an apartment with her friends. In Egypt, where personal freedom can be routinely compromised in the name of religion, family and country, that makes her a rebel. Like many in her generation, she is gasping for change. Can she win?

item.title: Major Royal News. Impose Story of Your Choice.
item.media:description: The Duchess and Duke of Cambridge after the birth of their son, Prince George, in 2013.
item.description: “Because there is so little material of substance to go on, because the public is allowed to see only public events, we impose on them any narrative we like.”
item.dc:creator: SARAH LYALL

item.title: U.A.E. Denies Yemen Rebels Fired Missile at Abu Dhabi Nuclear Plant
item.media:description: Houthi fighters in Sana, Yemen, on Sunday.
item.description: The Houthi rebels claimed they had launched a cruise missile against the $20 billion plant in retaliation for a Saudi-led blockade.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: China’s Top Ideologue Calls for Tight Control of Internet
item.media:description: Wang Huning spoke Sunday at the opening of the fourth World Internet Conference in Wuzhen, China.
item.description: Speaking to an audience that included the heads of Apple and Google, Wang Huning said China should be free to govern, and censor, its internet.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: Saleh’s Offer to ‘Turn a New Page’ in Yemen Is Welcomed by Saudi Coalition
item.description: Ali Abdullah Saleh, the former president of Yemen, said he was ready for a “new page” in ties with the Saudi-led coalition if it stopped attacks on his country.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Reporter’s Notebook: Pope Defends His Myanmar Diplomacy: ‘I Did Not Negotiate With the Truth’
item.media:description: Pope Francis, during a news conference aboard his plane on Saturday, said he was “very satisfied” with the meetings he had in Myanmar and Bangladesh.
item.description: Pope Francis, criticized for not using the word “Rohingya” while in Myanmar, said that using the term “would have been a door slammed in the face.”
item.dc:creator: JASON HOROWITZ

item.title: A Man Among Female Leaders: ‘The Risk of Mansplaining Is Very High’
item.media:description: A rare man at a summit of women political leaders: Xavier Prats Monné turns heads in his suit.
item.description: A Times reporter shadows a male speaker at a summit meeting of female political leaders in Iceland, the most gender-egalitarian country in the world.
item.dc:creator: KATRIN BENNHOLD

item.title: At Iran Sanctions Trial: A Star Witness Revealed, and a Sleepy Juror
item.media:description: Reza Zarrab in Istanbul in 2013. He has testified in a New York trial about how he carried out a scheme to smuggle Turkish gold for Iranian oil.
item.description: Here’s what we’ve learned in the first week of a Manhattan trial over a vast, billion-dollar conspiracy to violate United States sanctions by swapping Turkish gold for Iranian oil.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN WEISER

item.title: A Wary Response, So Far, on Trump’s Expected Recognition of Jerusalem
item.media:description: The Damascus Gate to Jerusalem’s Old City. President Trump is expected to break decades of precedent by declaring Jerusalem the capital of Israel.
item.description: Arabs and Israelis alike were impatient to see whether Mr. Trump would really declare Jerusalem the capital of Israel and how he might hedge it.
item.dc:creator: DAVID M. HALBFINGER

item.title: Emiratis Arrest Egyptian Presidential Candidate Ahmed Shafik, Lawyer Says
item.media:description: Ahmed Shafik in 2012, when he narrowly lost Egypt’s only free presidential election.
item.description: The authorities planned to deport Mr. Shafik, who has been living in the United Arab Emirates, back to Egypt, his lawyer said. He could face treason charges.
item.dc:creator: NOUR YOUSSEF and DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: In a Venezuela Ravaged by Inflation, ‘a Race for Survival’
item.media:description: A couple looking at the newly increased prices for food in a store’s window display in Caracas. Venezuelans of all economic classes have been buffeted by sharply rising costs.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Venezuelans of all classes have been hit hard by sharply rising costs, and the economic turmoil has turned the most basic tasks — like food shopping and commuting — into feats of endurance.
item.dc:creator: KIRK SEMPLE

item.title: How Ireland Moved to the Left: ‘The Demise of the Church’
item.media:description: A vigil in Dublin in October commemorating the fifth anniversary of the death of Savita Halappanavar, who died after she was denied a medically recommended abortion following a miscarriage.
item.media:credit: Niall Carson/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.description: In recent years, the one-time bastion of Catholic conservatism has moved left on same-sex marriage and gay rights, and is poised to repeal a constitutional ban on abortion.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
